message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of Raynaud phenomenon, and physical examination reveals nodules and ulcers on his foot and fingers, suggesting he has Buerger disease. The biopsy of the dorsalis pedis artery will most likely show segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina, which is characteristic of Buerger disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical examination findings suggest he has thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger’s disease). Biopsy of the dorsalis pedis artery will most likely show segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina, which is a characteristic finding in this condition. A, C, and D are not characteristic findings of thromboangiitis obliterans.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and clinical findings suggest Buerger disease, which is associated with segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina. A biopsy of the dorsalis pedis artery would show the same findings. The other options are not associated with this condition or do not match the pathological features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presented with painful nodules and ulcers, along with a history of Raynaud's phenomenon, which suggests the diagnosis of Buerger's disease. The most common finding on biopsy of affected arteries is segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina. Option A is more commonly seen in giant cell arteritis, option C is seen in atherosclerotic disease, and option D is seen in polyarteritis nodosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has recurrent episodes of color changes in his fingers when exposed to the cold suggests a diagnosis of Raynaud's phenomenon. The nodules on the left foot with surrounding erythema that follow the course of the lateral marginal vein suggest erythema nodosum, which can be associated with various underlying conditions such as infections or inflammatory diseases, but can also occur in patients with malignancies or vascular disorders such as polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). Biopsy of the dorsalis pedis artery will most likely show segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina, which is a characteristic finding in PAN.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Buerger’s disease. Among the options, segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina is the typical finding in Buerger's disease. Granulomatous inflammation with narrowing of the vessel lumen may indicate Takayasu arteritis, calcification of the tunica media with foam cells and fibrous cap formation may indicate atherosclerosis, and transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall may indicate polyarteritis nodosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest he has Raynaud’s disease. The multiple tender, dark purple nodules on the lateral surface of the left foot with surrounding erythema that follow the course of the lateral marginal vein suggest cutaneous polyarteritis nodosa. Biopsy of the dorsalis pedis artery will most likely show segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina, as this is the characteristic finding of cutaneous polyarteritis nodosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Buerger's disease, which is characterized by segmental thrombosing inflammation involving the small and medium-sized arteries in the extremities. This leads to narrowing or occlusion of the lumen, and the affected arteries become tender, erythematous, and nodular. Biopsy of the affected vessel would most likely show segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina. Granulomatous inflammation with narrowing of the vessel lumen is characteristic of Takayasu arteritis, calcification of the tunica media with foam cells and fibrous cap formation is characteristic of atherosclerosis, and transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of Raynaud phenomenon and the physical examination suggests cutaneous polyarteritis nodosa. Biopsy of the affected artery will most likely show segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina, which is characteristic of cutaneous polyarteritis nodosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Buerger's disease, which is characterized by segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina. Option A describes findings in giant cell arteritis, Option C describes findings in atherosclerosis, and Option D describes findings in polyarteritis nodosa.
